facts.text: Appeal confined to survey No. 86/2 at Mundhava in Poona district.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is confined to survey No. 86/2 at Mundhava in Poona district. The principal question arising for decision in the ap. peal is whether

facts.text: Ramabai owned two inam lands at Mundhava numbered Pratibhandi Nos. 71 and 72, corresponding to present survey Nos. 86/1 and 86/2.

anchor.surface_text: The present respondents are the daughter and grand sons of the original plaintiff Vinayakbhat. His adoptive mother was Ramabai. She owned two inam lands at

facts.text: On 1st July 1863, Ramabai passed permanent lease of both lands to Ladha Ibrahim Sheth for premium Rs. 999, yearly rent Rs. 80 during lifetime, then assessment to heirs; default ends tenant rights.

facts.text: On 18th August 1870, Ladha Ibrahim sold tenancy rights to Girdhari Balaram Lodhi for Rs. 7,999; sale deed provides default no rights; purchaser passed rent note to Ramabai for payment in Poush yearly, default no right.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 and other defendants are grandsons of Seth Girdhari Balaram.

facts.text: Lessee habitual defaulter in payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the nullity clause in the lease it appears that the lessee has been more or less a habitual defaulter in the payment of rent.

facts.text: In 1913, rent for six years in arrears; Vinayakbhat filed Suit No. 99 of 1913 against defendants for possession on forfeiture; defenses incl no notice; court negatived, granted relief against forfeiture; Def1 minor then, major ~1925.

facts.text: In 1928, rent for two years in arrears; Vinayakbhat filed Civil Suit No. 258 of 1928 for possession; waived by accepting three years rent and costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1928 again rent for two years was in arrears. Vinayakbhat filed Civil Suit No. 258 of 1928 against the present defendants for possession on

facts.text: In 1931, rent for three years in arrears; sent by money order, accepted by landlord.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1931 rent for three years again fell into arrears. The amount was then sent by money order and the landlord accepted it.

facts.text: In 1934, rent for three years unpaid; govt acquisition of old survey No. 72; landlord claimed full compensation; Def1 sent notice, paid arrears, forfeiture waived; defendants got Rs.32,000, Vinayakbhat Rs.1,400.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1934 again rent for three years remained unpaid. At that time proceedings were started by Government for the acquisition of the old survey No.

facts.text: In 1938, rent for four years in arrears; Vinayakbhat filed Suit No. 982 of 1938 for possession of 86/1 and 86/2; Def1 pleaded no forfeiture as no rent fixed, plaintiff to recover; negatived, forfeiture held but relief granted; DJ no interfere, warned no fourth time.

facts.text: Default on 28th January 1941; plaintiff filed Suit No. 858 of 1941 for possession of 86/1 and 86/2 and arrears; alleged rent due not paid though demanded.

facts.text: Trial court (Extra Joint Sub-Judge Poona) decreed suit on 31st March 1943; no notice needed; no relief due to contumacious conduct; possession entire to plaintiff, Def1 structures till end March 1950.

facts.text: Def1 appealed to District Judge Poona, confirmed decree 19th March 1945 with mods: allow remove buildings/trees on 86/2 in 3 months; no notice needed pre-TPA.

holdings.text: Notice in writing under section 111(g) of the Transfer of Property Act is not necessary for determination of a lease by forfeiture for non-payment of rent where the lease was executed prior to the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease pre-dates TPA 1882 (s2 exclusion); 1929 amendment to s111(g) prospective only (s63 Act XX 1929); institution of suit manifests election; supported by English law and pre-TPA Indian precedents.

holdings.text: The provision requiring notice in writing in section 111(g) TPA (as amended in 1929) is a mere statutory procedural formality and not a principle of justice, equity and good conscience applicable to pre-TPA leases.

anchor.surface_text: The main point for consideration thus is whether the particular provision introduced in sub-section g of section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act in 1929 is but a statutory recognition of a principle of justice, equity and good conscience,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insistence on written notice indicates statutory origin not equity; equity unconcerned with forms; English law requires no notice for rent forfeiture; pre-1929 law required only overt act like suit.

holdings.text: The lower courts properly exercised discretion in refusing relief against forfeiture under section 114 TPA due to tenant's habitual default, contumacious conduct, and false defenses over 25 years.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the tenant should have been given relief against forfeiture the High Court held that the matter was one of discretion and both the lower courts had exercised their discretion against the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion under s114 is wide (Hyman v Rose); considers parties' conduct; tenant recalcitrant, chronic defaulter, sued repeatedly, false excuses; clean hands doctrine bars relief; no rigid rules mandating relief if rent paid.

holdings.text: Umar Pulavar v Dawood Rowther was wrongly decided; amended s111(g) does not embody equity principle applicable to pre-TPA or agricultural leases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Overbroad view that TPA provisions always reflect equity; ignores no notice under English law for rent default and pre-1929 s111(g); courts cautious in applying excluded TPA provisions as equity.

holdings.text: Not every provision or amendment in TPA embodies principles of justice, equity and good conscience; each must be examined individually.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examples like s105 (definition), s107 (registration), s108(j) (transfer) are technical/statutory not equity-based; s117 excludes agricultural leases but equity application case-by-case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the provision as to notice in writing as a preliminary to a suit for ejectment based on forfeiture of a lease is not based on any principle of justice, equity or good conscience and cannot govern leases made prior to the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, or to leases executed prior to 1st April, 1930. The rights and obligations under those leases have to be determined according to the rules of law prevailing -at the time and the only rule applicable seems to be that a tenant cannot by his unilateral act and by his own wrong determine the lease unless the lessor gives an indication by some unequivocal expression of intention on his part of taking advantage of the breach. On no principle of equity is a tenant entitled to a notice in writing telling him that the lease has been determined. The High Court was therefore right in the view that it took of the matter and there are no valid reasons for taking a contrary view.

outcome.relief_summary: Supreme Court upholds High Court decree confirming possession to respondents on forfeiture of lease for non-payment of rent; no notice under section 111(g) TPA required for pre-Act lease; relief against forfeiture denied due to tenant's habitual default and contumacious conduct.
